- Marcos, thanks so much
for joining us today.
- Absolutely, pleasure to be here.

- Could you spend a little time
and tell us about, you know,

your background, your career,
Unqork, and your role there?
- Sure, so I'm the

Global Chief Information
Security Officer at Unqork.
I have a pretty diverse background.

Prior to Unqork, I was at
Gartner as their global CISO
for about four years.
Before then I was at a hedge fund company,
Bridgewater Associates.
Prior to that I was in consulting.
I also used to teach cybersecurity courses
as as an adjunct faculty member.

Absolutely, so little bit
of sort of everything there.
And also I was in the military,

so that's where I got really
in, started into cybersecurity,
more on the technical side.

- Great, and then your
roles and responsibilities
at Unqork itself?

- Yeah, so at Unqork, I'm
responsible for everything
from the internal side of security,
so ensuring that our employees are safe

and our endpoints and
technology is protected.
Also, the platform security as well.
So ensuring that our customers

that are building
applications on the platform,
that they're doing so secure securely.
So I have a team that's focused on
strategy and risk management.
Another team focused on product security.

So working really closely
with our developers

making sure that our
infrastructure is secure

cuz we deliver the
platform as a SAS product.
So from a infrastructure perspective,
we have to deal with all the accounts
in the backend ecosystem.
I have another team that's focused
on threat detection and response.

So everything from alerting,
monitoring, logging,
instant response.

And then I have another
team that's focused
on customer application security.
So really working closely

with our professional
services organization

and our customers, to
ensure that the applications

that they're built with no code,
that they're done securely.

- So, Marcos, tell me a
little bit about Unqork.

- So Unqork is an enterprise,
no code SAS platform

that allows enterprises to
build complex applications
without writing a single line of code.

We serve customers in
financial services, insurance,
healthcare, and the federal government.

And have to work with them to
ensure that they're building

out secure applications
without writing code.
- Fantastic.

So, as security teams have
evolved over the years
and more adoption of cloud has happened,

we've seen a shift from
sort of what I'll call the

traditional point and
click security operations

versus security engineering,
building security as code,

deploying through pipelines,
that sort of thing.
Could you share with us a little bit
how that change has happened at Unqork?
- Sure, absolutely.
So I think really it's twofold.

One, working really
closely with our developers

our engineers to, you know, to
use a buzz word, shift left.
And I think really trying to figure out
how to operationalize that,
and I think it extends beyond tools.
Tools is absolutely a big piece.

Ensuring that you can be a part
of that developer's process,
that pipeline.
Everything from pre-commit to commit hooks

checking for things such as
are we using the appropriate

design patterns that
were already pre-vetted
and pre-approved,

running certain scans,
and if certain conditions
are not met, perhaps ensuring,

not allowing that build
to proceed forward.
Things of that nature.
So I think that's one big aspect of it.
The second, kind of, as you alluded to,

ensuring that the security
teams are using code themselves

as necessary to ensure
automation, to ensure scalability.
This is key as you think about,

you know threat intelligence
and enrichment and monitoring.
Trying to monitor at scale really requires

the appropriate technology
and engineering expertise
to kind of keep up and do so.

- So Marcos, another change
we've seen is, you know

sort of the perception of
the CISO over the years.
Not too long ago the CISO was viewed

as a technical security
expert who, you know
basically just kept the company safe

and was referred to when
things went bad, right?
- Mmhhmm.

- But what we've seen
it sort of evolve into
is the CISO being a business partner

and a business enabler
for the larger business.

So I was wondering if
there's been any examples

that you have where maybe
you had a security program

or problem that you were
solving that also happened

to solve a business problem
or maybe vice versa.
- Sure, sure.
It's a great question.

We actually had a high
profile government customer,
federal customer,

that had an extremely
high bar for security.

And as part of that, the
business as you may imagine,

they were excited, they
wanted to make sure
that we can land this particular customer

but in order to do
business with this customer

we had to meet some very
stringent security requirements
which included only using these services
and tools that they had already vetted
and approved through their very rigorous
kind of security assessment program.
So essentially we had three options.

Option one was to onboard
all the pre-approved

and already vetted
services as well as tools

that the government
had already authorized.
As you may imagine,

we did not have the
appropriate logging pipelines
for those different tools.
They all have different formats.

Sometimes the field names and
the like would be different.

And so trying to do all
the work to analyze that
and to onboard into our existing pipelines
likely would've been a challenge.
The second option was to seek approval
from the government for our existing tools
and our services that we're already using.

The challenge there
was, as you may imagine

is a very hefty process to
go through that full review
and assessment.

And we likely would've
delayed the project.

We likely would've perhaps
not even gotten that approval.
And so ultimately we didn't want to,

we didn't wanna slow down
the business' momentum.
Option three would've been,
really just ingesting all of those logs

into our sim directly from a
raw log format perspective.

As you may imagine,
that's cost-prohibitive.

Trying to ingest all of
those logs from new services,
new tools, is gonna gonna raise the cost.

And so we essentially looked
at it from a perspective of
how do we weigh the pros and cons?

What is the appropriate mechanism
to make a decision so that
we can enable the business to move quickly
to close this deal?

We can still ensure that we
have a level of visibility

and monitoring from a
security perspective,

and we meet the requirements
that are bestowed
upon us by this customer.
So our decision was,

we're essentially gonna
go with option one,
which was to use the existing tools

but how could we rapidly
onboard those new tools

and ingest 'em into a data
model that made sense for us
from a monitoring perspective.

So we decided to build a
new cloud native serverless
logging solution.

Essentially that solution
allowed us to parse the logs,

to normalize the logs, and
to inline filter those logs.

So having to go into
the details if you like,
- Please do.
Sure, sure.

So essentially we use
cloudnative AWS services.

And so the logs in the
raw pre-processed format,
will go into s3.

We use SNS to send a message
and notification to SQS.
SQS was configured with a lambda function
as that log processor front door.
And so once a new log was available
and needed to be processed

that front door would pick
it up, in that S3 bucket.
And then from there it would look at the
the type of log that it is.

And so over a dozen kind of
log types and log formats.

And then it would, it would
spawn out to another set
of queues as well as lambda functions
based upon that specific log type.
For example, it could be WAF logs,
it could be low balance logs, et cetera.
And that's because each log type
had to be processed differently.
Some log types were in json,
others were in, you know, text format.
Some were very difficult to process.

And so they, they spawned out
to those individual queues
and lambda functions where it was parsed,
it was normalized, it was filtered.
And then from there it would go
off to a final queue and lambda function

where it would then be sent
out to our worm sim storage.

So we had to build that out
in about two months time.

Which was quite the feat
that that we embarked upon.
But the team did a very proud
of my threat detection and response team

to build that solution in
the time that it was built.
Ultimately it met the requirements

of our government customer,
our business was happy
we were able to land the deal.

We were able to do so in a
way that maintained security
and maintain visibility.
We were able to ingest all of those logs
and having them normalized in our schema,
in our data model was very important
from an enrichment perspective,

from a data monitoring
and alerting perspective
and so forth.
So at the end of the day,
we filtered down to keep only one 100th

of the logs that were
pushed to that sim storage.
- Oh, wow.

- And so when you think about
the ability to scale that,
it's massive.

You know, when we sort of
scale that architecture

now we're looking at
probably seven figures
of cost savings to the business,
while also allowing the business to

to seal that deal with
the government customer.

- I would call that
significant business impact.
- Absolutely, absolutely.
- So have you been able to
leverage that system that you built

across other customers that
you've had or used that as

an enticement to get other

- So not just yet.
That is a new design pattern that
we're now looking at how do we scale this
across other customer environments as well
because ultimately it's a good opportunity

for us to take advantage
of that scalability,

that, you know, elasticity and
using that common data model.
The other benefit of that data model is

we also on the backend
build visualizations
based on those log sources as well.
So that way an analyst can look at it
and all that normalization allows them to
do that comparison in a more visual way
as opposed to needing to go through
and sift through raw logs.

most successful customers

have a very strong

So security is baked in early

One of the things that I like

Unqork hired a security officer

- Oh wow.

- And that's actually one of
the reasons I joined Unqork.

on security from day one,

kind of permeates
throughout our organization
and our culture.

as part of working through
helping to reinforce that culture.
Whether within my leadership team,

as I'm having different discussions,

the different councils and
committees and so forth.
And so we have a wide variety

whether it's just through

ad hoc, kind of spot reports
around what's happening
around the world.

How our employees can
help as part of that.
And so we're always looking at ways

is training them on how to threat model
their own application.

As I mentioned, you

How do you shift behaviors and thinking.

to help them understand

within their application.

What are the things that
